author: Sunita Sekar
text:
A pet dog slurps water from a bowl kept out for animals as part of Waterbowl Challenge in Chennai —Photo: M. Vedhan

During summer people ensure they get enough hydration to beat the heat. However, when street dogs and cats suffer the scorching heat, they may not always find water.

This thought gave birth to ‘The Water Bowl Challenge’. The initiative encourages people to provide water to animals, says Arun Prasanna of People for Cattle in India (PFCI) which organised the event. The challenge requires people to provide a bowl of water — at their houses, gardens, offices or on streets — to help animals quench their thirst and post a picture of this on PFCI’s social media page.

During the launch of the event on Sunday, Arun Prasanna of PFCI said, “Animals can survive without food, but not without water. During this season, we get a lot of rescue calls about animals suffering from dehydration; that’s what prompted us to start such this challenge.”

Two years ago, when the challenge was started, the initiative did not elicit the expected response as the bowls were given free of cost and not many cared to do it. “When we went to check how successful the challenge was, the first time, we realised that what was given freely was taken for granted and several households did not keep out water everyday,” he says.

So, from the second year on, they charged Rs. 200 for a bowl. The strategy worked, as expected.
title: Waterbowl challenge gets rolling
